levels: What happens to current when you apply a very high voltage across a low resistance? Can you think of why that might be dangerous?
Your current just hit {current}mA with only {resistance} ohms. What does Ohm's Law tell you about the relationship between V, I, and R here?
At {voltage}V and {resistance} ohms, current = V/R = {current}mA. Real components have max ratings — your circuit just exceeded them. Try reducing voltage below 12V or increasing resistance.
What do you think happens to current flow when resistance gets extremely small? Why might that be a problem?
Your resistance is near {resistance} ohms — what would the calculated current be? Is that physically realistic?
With near-zero resistance, current approaches infinity (I = V/R). Real wires melt and fuses blow. Keep resistance above 10 ohms to simulate realistic circuits.
The projectile went very far. What variables control how far something travels when thrown? Which one has the biggest effect?
At {velocity}m/s and {angle} degrees, the range exceeded the field. Which parameter would you reduce to keep the projectile in bounds?
Range = v squared times sin(2 times angle) divided by g. High velocity has quadratic effect. Try velocity below 30 m/s or angles away from 45 degrees.
The projectile didn't travel at all. What conditions would make an object land exactly where it started?
Your launch angle is {angle} degrees. At 0 degrees and 90 degrees, what horizontal distance would you expect?
At 0 degrees, all velocity is horizontal but there's no loft. At 90 degrees, it goes straight up and comes straight down. Try something between 20 and 70 degrees.
You're using a very steep angle. What happens to horizontal range as the angle approaches 90 degrees?
At {angle} degrees, most velocity goes upward. If you want maximum distance, what angle maximizes sin(2 times theta)?
Maximum range occurs at exactly 45 degrees because sin(90) = 1. Your angle of {angle} degrees gives sin({twoAngle}) = {sinValue}, much less efficient.
You've moved past the equivalence point. What does pH do when you add excess base to a neutralized solution?
With {baseVolume}mL added, the equivalence point was around 25mL. What happens to the extra hydroxide ions?
Past the equivalence point, excess OH minus ions accumulate, pushing pH above 10 rapidly. The curve flattens because the solution is already basic.
The enzyme stopped working. What environmental factor could cause a protein to lose its 3D shape?
At {temperature} degrees C, the enzyme denatured. Most enzymes have an optimal range — what temperature is that for human enzymes?
Proteins unfold above ~65 degrees C (denaturation). Human enzymes work best at 37 degrees C. This is irreversible — like cooking an egg.
I notice the power dissipation is getting high. What happens to real resistors when they dissipate too much heat?
Your circuit is drawing {current}mA. Many standard resistors are rated for only 0.25W. What's the power here?
At {voltage}V and {current}mA, power = {power}W. Standard 1/4W resistors would overheat. Consider reducing voltage or increasing resistance.

projectile-motion.condition_description: Velocity above 40 m/s or angle above 80 degrees
levels: Your parameters are pushing toward extreme values. In real experiments, what practical limits would you face?
At {velocity}m/s, your projectile would need significant launch energy. Is this realistic for a classroom setup?
Practical launchers rarely exceed 30 m/s. Angles near 90 degrees waste energy — the projectile goes straight up and comes back down.
You're approaching a critical region. In titration, what happens to pH change per drop near the equivalence point?
Between 24-26mL, pH changes dramatically per 0.1mL added. Why does the curve become nearly vertical here?
At equivalence (~25mL), moles acid = moles base. A single drop swings pH by 4-6 units because there's no buffer capacity left.
Your object is very close to a special distance. What happens to the image when the object sits at certain key positions?
Object at {objectDistance}cm with focal length {focalLength}cm — you're near u = f. What does the lens formula give for image distance?
When object distance equals focal length, 1/v = 1/f - 1/f = 0, so v approaches infinity. The image forms at infinity — rays become parallel.
Your temperature is getting very high. In real chemistry, what side effects can extreme heat cause beyond speeding up the reaction?
At {temperature} degrees C, the Arrhenius factor is very large. But what about the catalyst or enzyme stability?
Above 80 degrees C, many catalysts degrade. The Arrhenius equation predicts exponential rate increase, but real systems have thermal limits.

ohm-law: Looking at your current setup with {voltage}V and {resistance} ohms: Which parameter do you think has a bigger effect on current — and why?
Try doubling just the resistance. What happens to the current? Now try doubling the voltage instead. See the symmetry?
Here's a challenge: Can you find the voltage and resistance combination that gives exactly 100mA? Use I = V/R.
projectile-motion: What angle do you think gives maximum range? Try a few values and watch the trajectory change shape.
Notice that {angle} degrees and {complementary} degrees give the same range. Why do complementary angles produce equal distances?
Try fixing the angle at 45 degrees and changing velocity. See how range scales with velocity squared, not linearly.
titration: Watch the pH curve shape. Why is it flat at the start, steep in the middle, and flat again at the end?
With {baseVolume}mL added, you're in the buffer region. What provides the buffering capacity here?
Try adding base in 0.1mL increments near 25mL. Count how many drops it takes for pH to jump from 4 to 10.
optics-bench: With focal length {focalLength}cm, what happens when you place the object at exactly 2 times the focal length? Try it.
Move the object closer to the lens than the focal point. What changes about the image — position, orientation, size?
Real lenses have edge distortion called aberration. In this simulation, we use the thin lens equation which assumes a perfect lens.
reaction-rate: Chemical kinetics says rate depends on temperature and concentration. Which effect is stronger? Try testing both.
At {temperature} degrees C and {concentration}M, can you predict the rate before you see it? Use the van 't Hoff rule: rate doubles every 10 degrees.
Try increasing concentration from 1M to 2M at constant temperature. The rate should double — this is a first-order reaction.
general: What's one variable you haven't changed yet? Scientific method says test variables one at a time.
Can you predict what will happen before you press Run? Making predictions is the most important part of learning science.
What surprised you in this experiment? The gap between expectation and reality is where real understanding lives.
